Title: Academic Year
Summary: An academic year is one complete school year at the same school, or two complete, half years at different schools. For schools that have a year-round program of instruction, nine months is considered an academic year.

Title: Aid for Military Family Service
Summary: Both the federal government and nonprofit organizations offer money for college to veterans, future military personnel, active duty personnel, or those related to veterans or active duty personnel.

Title: Annual Taxable Income
Summary: Your annual taxable income is the amount of income used to determine how much tax you owe in a given year. This can include wages, salaries, bonuses, tips, investment income, and unearned income. If you have received a W-2 form or a 1099 form from an employer, you can find this number on those forms.

Title: Cookie
Summary: Cookies are bits of data that a website transfers to a computer’s hard drive. The most common use of cookies is for a website to determine your personal preferences. Some cookies disappear once you close the browser while some remain.

Title: Credit
Summary: Credit refers to the amount of money you borrow and your ability to borrow to purchase goods and services. Credit is extended to you from a credit grantor with which you make an agreement to pay back the amount spent, plus applicable interest and fees, within an agreed-upon time.

Title: Debt Collection
Summary: Debt collection is the course of pursuing payments of loan debts due by borrowers.

Title: Debt Consolidation
Summary: Debt consolidation is a method of debt refinancing that involves taking out one loan to pay off others.

Title: Default
Summary: Default is failure to repay a loan outlined in the agreed promissory note. Most federal student loan default occurs when a payment isn’t made in more than 270 days. It can result in legal consequences and a loss of eligibility for additional federal student aid.

Title: Deferment
Summary: A deferment is a temporary postponement of payment on a loan that is allowed under certain conditions and during which interest generally doesn’t accrue on certain types of subsidized loans.

Title: Direct Consolidation Loan
Summary: A Direct Consolidation Loan combines federal education loans into one loan for free via completion of the Federal Direct Consolidation Loan Application and Promissory Note. You will have a single monthly payment on the new Direct Consolidation Loan.

Title: Direct PLUS Loan
Summary: Direct PLUS Loans are federal loans that graduate or professional students and parents of dependent undergraduate students use to help pay for education expenses.

Title: Direct Subsidized Loan
Summary: A Direct Subsidized Loan is a federal student loan for which a borrower isn’t generally responsible for paying the interest while in an in-school, grace, or deferment period.

Title: Discretionary Income
Summary: Discretionary income is a factor used in determining a borrower’s eligibility for certain repayment plans and/or loan rehabilitation. It’s the difference between annual income and a percentage of the poverty guideline for the borrower’s family size and state of residence.

Title: Early Action
Summary: Early action is a college admission policy that allows applicants to apply and receive notice of their admission early. Applicants accepted under early action are not under a binding agreement to attend that school and may submit applications to other schools.

Title: Early Decision
Summary: Early decision is a college admission policy that allows applicants who commit to attend a school to apply and receive notice of their admission early. If an applicant is accepted, he or she agrees to attend that school and must withdraw all other applications.

Title: Educational Service Agency
Summary: An educational service agency is a regional public multiservice agency that is authorized by state law to develop, manage, and provide services or programs to local education agencies, such as public-school districts.

Title: Eligible Program
Summary: An eligible program is a program of organized instruction or study of a certain length that leads to an academic, professional, or vocational degree or certificate, or other recognized education credential.

Title: Emancipated Minor
Summary: An emancipated minor is someone who has been legally deemed an adult by a court in his or her state of residence before the age of 18. If you are an emancipated minor, you are considered an independent student and will not provide information about your parents on the FAFSA® form.

Title: Endorser
Summary: An endorser is someone who agrees to repay the Direct PLUS Loan if the borrower becomes delinquent in making payments or defaults on the loan. The endorser may not be the student on whose behalf a parent obtains a Direct PLUS Loan.

Title: Endorser Code
Summary: An Endorser Code is an identifying number associated to a Direct PLUS Loan application. The code is used by an endorser when completing a Direct PLUS Loan endorser addendum to the Master Promissory Note (MPN) for the loan.

Title: Enrollment Status
Summary: Enrollment status is reported by the school you attended, and indicates whether you are, or were, full-time, three-quarter time, half-time, less than half-time, withdrawn, graduated, etc.

Title: Entrance Counseling
Summary: Entrance counseling explains your rights and the obligations you agree to meet as a condition of accepting a Direct Loan. More information about entrance counseling is available at: https://studentaid.gov/entrance-counseling/.

Title: Exit Counseling
Summary: Exit counseling provides important information to prepare you repay your federal student loan(s). Topics include: Contact Settings, My Loans, Preparing to Repay, Determining Your Repayment Strategy. Exit counseling is available at: https://studentaid.gov/exit-counseling/.

Title: Extended Repayment Plan
Summary: The Extended Repayment Plan allows you to repay your loans over an extended period. Payments are made for up to 25 years. There are specific eligibility requirements to qualify for this plan.

Title: Family Size
Summary: Household size does not mean people who physically live with you. It’s about who you support financially. If you do not financially support anyone, you will just put 1 for yourself.

Title: Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) program
Summary: The Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) Program was a program that worked with private lenders to provide education loans guaranteed by the federal government. The FFEL Program ended in 2010. All loans are now made through the Direct Loan Program.

Title: Federal Pell Grant program
Summary: The Pell Grant is the largest federal grant program offered to undergraduates. It is designed to assist students from low-income households. To qualify for a Pell Grant, a student must demonstrate financial need by completing and submitting the FAFSA® form.

Title: Federal Perkins Loan
Summary: A Perkins Loan was available to undergraduate, graduate, and professional students until Sept. 30, 2017; the program has since expired. The Perkins Loan is a subsidized loan, meaning the federal government pays the loan’s interest while the borrower is in school.

Title: Federal Student Aid
Summary: Federal student aid is aid from the government in the form of grants, loans, and/or work-study to assist students with college or career school. Students have to complete the FAFSA® form to apply for this aid.

Title: Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grant (FSEOG)
Summary: The Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grant (FSEOG) is a grant that is awarded to an undergraduate student who demonstrates exceptional financial need to help pay for their education. Awards can range from $100–$4000 and do not need to be repaid.

Title: Federal Work Study
Summary: Federal Work-Study provides part-time jobs for undergraduate and graduate students with financial need. The program encourages community service work and work related to your field of study. To receive funds, you will need to be awarded work study and secure a job.

Title: Financial Aid
Summary: Financial aid is money to help pay for college or career school.

Title: Financial Awareness Counseling
Summary: Financial awareness counseling provides tools and information to help you understand your financial aid and assist in managing your finances. Topics include: Understand Your Loans, Manage Your Spending, Plan to Repay, Avoid Default and Make Finances a Priority.

Title: Forbearance
Summary: A period of time when your monthly loan payments are temporarily stopped or reduced. Interest will continue to be charged on your loans. Be aware that unpaid interest may be capitalized (added to your loan principal balance) at the end of your forbearance period.

Title: FSA ID
Summary: An FSA ID consists of a username and password which gives you access to the U.S. Department of Education’s online systems and can serve as your legal signature when completing electronic documents.

Title: Full-Time Teacher
Summary: A teacher is a person who provides direct classroom teaching or classroom-type teaching in a non-classroom setting, including special education teachers. Full-time indicates working 32 hours or more in a single job.

Title: Graduate or Professional Student
Summary: A graduate or professional student is a student who is pursuing education opportunities beyond an undergraduate (bachelor’s) degree. Graduate and professional programs include master’s and doctoral programs such as Ph.D., J.D., and M.D., among others.

Title: Graduated Repayment Plan
Summary: The Graduated Repayment Plan starts with lower payments that increase every two years. Under this plan, you make payments for up to 10 years (between 10 and 30 years for consolidation loans).

Title: Graduation Rate
Summary: A school’s graduation rate is the percentage of a school’s full-time, first-time degree- or certificate-seeking students who complete their degree or certificate within 150 percent of the published length of the program in which they are enrolled.

Title: Grant
Summary: A grant is a monetary gift for people pursuing higher education. It is often based on financial need and does not need to be repaid (unless, for example, you withdraw from school and owe a refund).

Title: Gross Income
Summary: Gross income is your total income before deductions.

Title: Guaranty Agency
Summary: A guaranty agency is a state or private non-profit agency that helps administer the Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) Program. A guaranty agency insures federal loans by repaying the loan holder when a loan defaults, and then collects the defaulted loan from the borrower.

Title: Half-Time Enrollment
Summary: Half-time enrollment is an enrollment status applied to students who are only enrolled in half of the expected full-time course load. Half-time enrollment can affect the cost of attendance (COA), and each school may have different half-time enrollment specifications.

Title: Head of Household
Summary: For tax purposes, you might claim head of household if you are unmarried and responsible for more than half of the cost of keeping up your and your dependent’s home. Whether you are head of household can affect how you report tax return information on the FAFSA® form.

Title: Homeless
Summary: A homeless individual is someone without a home who generally lives in shelters, parks, motels, hotels, cars, or with someone else due to not having anywhere else to go. Homeless individuals can still receive federal student aid.

Title: Income-Based Repayment (IBR) Plan
Summary: Eligible loans: Direct loans and FFEL Program loans other than those in default, PLUS loans made to a parent borrower, or Consolidation Loans that repaid a Direct or Federal PLUS Loan made to a parent borrower. Consolidating a Federal Perkins Loan may make you eligible.

Title: Income-Contingent Repayment (ICR) Plan
Summary: Eligible loans: Direct loans other than those in default and parent PLUS loans. Consolidating a Federal Perkins Loan, FFEL Program loan or Direct PLUS Loan made to a parent may make you eligible.

Title: Independent Student
Summary: An independent student is at least 24 years old, married, a graduate/ professional student, a veteran, a member of the armed forces, an orphan, a ward of the court, someone with legal dependents (not a spouse), an emancipated minor, or someone who is or at risk of being homeless.

Title: Interest
Summary: Interest is a loan expense charged for the use of borrowed money. Interest is paid by a borrower to a lender. The expense is calculated as a percentage of the unpaid principal amount of the loan.

Title: Iraq and Afghanistan Service Grant (IASG)
Summary: You may be eligible for the Iraq and Afghanistan Service Grant (IASG) if your parent or guardian died as a result of military service performed in Iraq or Afghanistan after the events of 9/11, and you are not eligible for a Federal Pell Grant.

Title: Job Placement Rate
Summary: A school’s job placement rate is the percentage of graduating students who obtained employment either in the recognized occupation for which they were trained or in a related, comparable, recognized occupation within a determined period after receiving their degree/certificate.

Title: Judgment Lien
Summary: A judgment lien gives a creditor the legal right to keep property when the owner fails to pay a debt. It can only be granted by a court. A student (or parent in the case of a parent borrower) with a judgment lien will not qualify for federal student aid.

Title: Legal Guardianship
Summary: Legal guardianship is a designation by a court that authorizes someone to care for an individual in place or absence of parents. Having a legal guardian qualifies you as an independent student, such that you do not have to report your parents’ income on the FAFSA® form.

Title: Lender
Summary: A lender is the organization that made the loan (borrower’s school, bank, credit union, etc.).

Title: Litigation
Summary: Litigation is the act or process of bringing or contesting a legal action in court.

Title: Loan
Summary: A loan is money borrowed from the federal government or a private source like a bank or financial institution, and must be paid back with interest.

Title: Loan Discharge
Summary: Loan discharge is the removal of a borrower’s obligation to repay a loan under certain circumstances including but not limited to death, disability, bankruptcy, fraud, and identity theft.

Title: Loan Forgiveness
Summary: Student loan forgiveness is offered to encourage certain types of employment. A loan may be fully or partially forgiven after a certain number of years of qualifying employment.

Title: Master Promissory Note (MPN)
Summary: An MPN is a legal document that contains the Borrower’s Rights and Responsibilities and Terms and Conditions for repayment. Direct PLUS and Direct Subsidized / Unsubsidized loans have different MPNs. Access the MPN at: https://studentaid.gov/mpn.

Title: Merit-Based
Summary: Merit-based means that something is based on a student’s skill or ability. For example, a merit-based scholarship might be awarded based on a student’s high grades.

Title: Offset
Summary: An offset is when a payment from the U.S. Department of Treasury (such as an income tax refund) is reduced or stopped to pay off a delinquent debt. The remainder of a refund will be processed; an offset shouldn’t delay it unless the entire refund is applied to the debt.

Title: Ombudsman Group
Summary: The Ombudsman Group is dedicated to helping resolve disputes related to the federal student aid programs, including Direct Loans, Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) Program loans, Perkins Loans, and grant programs.

Title: Out-of-State Student
Summary: An out-of-state student is a student who is attending a college or career school outside of his or her state of legal residence.

Title: Partial Financial Hardship
Summary: Partial financial hardship is an eligibility requirement under the Income-Based Repayment and Pay As You Earn repayment plans. For more information, go to Repayment Plans.

Title: Pay As You Earn (PAYE) Plan
Summary: The Pay As You Earn Plan is a repayment plan with monthly payments that are generally equal to 10% of your discretionary income, but never more than the 10-year Standard Repayment amount.

Title: Payroll Deductions
Summary: Payroll deductions are amounts of money withheld from your paycheck by your employer.

Title: PLUS Credit Counseling
Summary: PLUS credit counseling helps graduate/professional students and parents of eligible dependent undergraduate students understand the obligations associated with borrowing a PLUS loan and assists them in making careful decisions about taking on student loan debt.

Title: Postbaccalaureate Teacher Certification Program
Summary: A postbaccalaureate teacher certification program is a program that enables those who hold at least a bachelor’s degree to earn teacher certification at the elementary or secondary level. Program specifics can depend on the school and state where the program is available.

Title: Prepaid Tuition
Summary: A prepaid tuition plan, also known as a section 529 plan, lets you lock in future tuition rates at in-state public colleges at current prices and is usually guaranteed by the state in which the plan was established.

Title: Principal
Summary: Principal refers to the sum of money lent, on which interest is paid.

Title: Proprietary School
Summary: A proprietary school is a private, for-profit school that provides education and training.

Title: Public Service Loan Forgiveness (PSLF) Help Tool
Summary: This tool will help you understand the following about the Public Service Loan Forgiveness (PSLF) Program: what is required to participate, if an employer qualifies, which loans qualify, and other actions to take to receive PSLF.

Title: Public Service Loan Forgiveness (PSLF) Program
Summary: The PSLF Program forgives the remaining balance on your Direct Loans after you have made 120 (10 years) qualifying monthly payments under a qualifying repayment plan, while working full-time for a qualifying employer.

Title: Regular Student
Summary: A regular student is one who is enrolled or accepted for enrollment at an institution for the purpose of obtaining a degree, certificate, or other recognized education credential. To be eligible for federal student aid, you must generally be a regular student.

Title: Rehabilitated Loan
Summary: Loan rehabilitation is one method of getting your student loan out of default. To begin the rehabilitation process, you must contact your loan holder. If you’re not sure who your loan holder is, log in to your account to get your loan holder’s contact information.

Title: Repayment
Summary: Repayment is paying back money you borrowed by making scheduled payments to a loan holder or servicer.

Title: Retention Rate
Summary: A school’s retention rate is the percentage of its first-time students who are seeking bachelor’s degrees who return to the institution to continue their studies the following fall.

Title: Revised Pay As You Earn (REPAYE) Plan
Summary: The REPAYE Plan is a repayment plan with monthly payments that are generally equal to 10% of your discretionary income.

Title: Room and Board
Summary: Room and board is generally the cost of housing and food while attending college or career school.

Title: Satisfactory Academic Progress
Summary: Satisfactory academic progress is the process a school uses to determine if a student is meeting all of his or her educational requirements and is on target to graduate on time with a degree or certificate. This process may vary across schools.

Title: Scholarships
Summary: Scholarships are gifts that don’t have to be repaid and are designed to help students pay for an undergraduate degree. They can be a one-time gift or are renewable, depending on the scholarship.

Title: School Closure
Summary: A school closure occurs when an institution no longer provides educational services to students.

Title: Service Obligation
Summary: A TEACH service obligation is an agreement to teach full-time, in a high-need field, at an elementary/secondary school/educational service agency for low-income students, and for at least four out of eight academic years following their ending of the grant assisted study.

Title: Standard Repayment Plan
Summary: The Standard Repayment Plan is the basic repayment plan for the William D. Ford Federal Direct Loan (Direct Loan) and Federal Family Education Loan (FFEL) Programs. Payments are fixed and made for up to 10 years (10–30 years for Consolidation Loans).

Title: Standardized Test
Summary: A standardized test is a test that is designed to assess individuals against a common standard. For example, the SAT and ACT are standardized tests that some colleges require for consideration for admission.

Title: State Aid
Summary: States offer financial assistance to eligible residents to help reduce educational costs. Some state aid is first come, first served, so complete your FAFSA® form early. We don’t administer state aid programs. Contact your state grant agency for more information.

Title: Student Fraud
Summary: Student Fraud is any situation where an individual falsifies information in order to qualify for student aid. Examples of student fraud include using false information on the FAFSA, such as income or marital status, or reporting an invalid high school diploma.

Title: Student Loan Debt Burden
Summary: Student loan debt burden is the percentage of a borrower’s monthly income that is dedicated to his or her student loan payments. The smaller this percentage, the lower the debt burden.

Title: Teach-Out Process
Summary: A teach-out process provides for the equitable treatment of students and a reasonable opportunity for students to complete their program of study if a school ceases to operate before they have completed their program of study.

Title: Teacher
Summary: A teacher is a person who provides professional direct instruction to students.

Title: Teacher Education Assistance for College and Higher Education (TEACH) Grant
Summary: The TEACH Grant funds students who are completing/plan to complete coursework that is required to be a teacher, and who agree to teach full-time in a high-need field at an educational service agency or school for low-income students for at least four years.

Title: Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) Discharge
Summary: A total and permanent disability discharge relieves you from having to repay your federal student loan(s) and/or complete your Teacher Education Assistance for College and Higher Education (TEACH) Grant service obligation. Learn more about TPD discharge.

Title: Transfer Rate
Summary: A school’s transfer rate is the percentage of its full-time, first-time students who have transferred to another institution.

Title: Transfer Student
Summary: A transfer student is a student who has completed some academic credits at a college or university and has requested to enroll at a different institution.

Title: Tuition
Summary: Tuition is the amount of money you owe for receiving instruction, materials, and/or supplies, or for the rental or purchase of equipment, for a course of study at your institution.

Title: Undergraduate Student
Summary: An undergraduate student is a student who is enrolled in an undergraduate course of study at a college/university or career school that usually doesn’t exceed four years and leads to an undergraduate degree or certificate.

Title: Unsubsidized Loan
Summary: An unsubsidized loan borrowed through the Direct Loan Program offers students a low, fixed interest rate and flexible repayment terms. It is not based on financial need. The borrower is responsible for paying all the accumulated interest, until the loan balance is paid off.

Title: Untaxed Income
Summary: Untaxed income is income you don’t pay taxes on, such as Supplemental Security Income, child support, or federal or public assistance.

Title: William D. Ford Federal Direct Loan Program
Summary: The Direct Loan Program is the federal student loan program under which eligible students and parents borrow directly from the U.S. Department of Education at participating schools. Loans include Direct Subsidized, Direct Unsubsidized, Direct PLUS, and Direct Consolidation Loans.

Title: Withholding
Summary: A withholding is an amount of money that an employer takes out of your wages and pays to the government. If too little is withheld, you will owe additional taxes. If too much is withheld, you receive a refund.

Title: FAFSA Step One
Summary: Step One of the FAFSA form asks for personal information from the student, including name, address, identification numbers, and education level for the relevant school year.

Title: FAFSA Question 1
Summary: Question 1 is asking for your last name. Enter in your last name as it appears on your Social Security Card.

Title: FAFSA Question 2
Summary: Question 2 is asking for your first name. Enter in your first name as it appears on your Social Security Card.

Title: FAFSA Question 3
Summary: Question 3 is asking for your middle initial. Enter in your middle initial, the first letter of your middle name, as it appears on your Social Security Card. If you don't have a middle name, leave this blank.

Title: FAFSA Question 4
Summary: Question 4 is asking for your permanent mailing address. A permanent is mailing address the address where your family resides and you can reliably get mail. If you don't have a permanent mailing address, use a mailing address where you can get mail. Enter your building number, street, and apartment number.

Title: FAFSA Question 5
Summary: Question 5 is asking for the city for your permanent mailing address. A permanent is mailing address the address where your family resides and you can reliably get mail. If you don't have a permanent mailing address, use a mailing address where you can get mail.

Title: FAFSA Question 6
Summary: Question 6 is asking for the state for your permanent mailing address. A permanent is mailing address the address where your family resides and you can reliably get mail. If you don't have a permanent mailing address, use a mailing address where you can get mail.

Title: FAFSA Question 7
Summary: Question 7 is asking for the zip code for your permanent mailing address. A permanent is mailing address the address where your family resides and you can reliably get mail. If you don't have a permanent mailing address, use a mailing address where you can get mail. If you don't know your zip code, you can look it up at https://tools.usps.com/zip-code-lookup.htm

Title: FAFSA Question 8
Summary: Question 8 is asking for your Social Security Number. Enter your Social Security Number as it appears on your Social Security card. Do not use dashes. This is required to be considered for Federal Student Aid. If you don't have access to it or you don't know where it is, you can request a new or replacement card from the Social Security Administration here: https://www.ssa.gov/ssnumber/

Title: FAFSA Question 9
Summary: Question 9 is asking for your date of birth. Enter your date of birth in “mmddyyyy” format. For example, if your birthday is May 3, 2005, enter 05032005.

Title: FAFSA Question 10
Summary: Question 10 is asking for your telephone number. Provide the area code to your telephone number first. Enter the numbers, without parentheses and dashes. For example, 2025551212. If you do not have a telephone number, you may leave this question blank.

Title: FAFSA Question 11
Summary: Question 11 is asking for the number on your state-issued identification card. Enter your driver's license number or the number on your identification card. If you do not have a driver's license or a state identification card, leave this field blank.

Title: FAFSA Question 12
Summary: Question 12 is asking for the state that issued you your identification card. Enter or select the two-letter state abbreviation for the state that issued your driver’s license or identification card. If you do not have a driver's license or a state identification card, leave this field blank.

Title: FAFSA Question 13
Summary: Question 13 is asking for your email address. Enter your e-mail address to receive important information about your financial aid application, such as your Student Aid Report (SAR), renewal reminders, and saved application reminders. A valid email address usually looks like this matt@yahoo.com or ashley@gmail.com. If you are filing online, you may have used your email address to create your FSA ID.

Title: FAFSA Question 14
Summary:
Question 14 is asking if you are a United States citizen. Select the option that indicates your citizenship status. Select U.S. citizen (or U.S. national) if you are a U.S. citizen or U.S. national. A person is a United States citizen by birth or by naturalization. Persons (except for the children of foreign diplomatic staff) who are born in the 50 states, the District of Columbia, and in most cases, Puerto Rico (PR), the U.S. Virgin Islands (VI), Guam (GU), and the Northern Marianna Islands (MP) are U.S. citizens, as are most persons born abroad to parents (or a parent) who are citizens. All U.S. citizens are considered to be U.S. nationals, but not all nationals are citizens: natives of American Samoa and Swain’s Island (AS)
are not U.S. citizens but are nationals.

Title: FAFSA Question 15
Summary: Question 15 is asking for your Alien Registration Number if you are not a United States citizen. Enter your eight- or nine-digit Alien Registration Number. If your Alien Registration Number is eight digits, enter a zero before the Alien Registration Number. Do not enter the “A” before the number. An answer is not required if you are a citizen of the Federated States of Micronesia, the Marshall Islands, or Palau.

Title: FAFSA Question 16
Summary: Question 16 is asking if you are married, or have previously been married. Enter the answer that describes your marital status as of the day you submit your Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA). If your marital status has changed or will change since the time the application was initially submitted, check with your institution’s financial aid office.

Title: FAFSA Question 17
Summary: Question 17 is asking for the date that your marital status changed (marriage, divorce, separation, or spouse's death). If you are single and have never been married, you can leave this blank.

Title: FAFSA Question 18
Summary: Question 18 is asking for which state you live in. Enter or select your current state or country of legal residence, which is frequently the state of your permanent mailing address. If responding electronically, select Foreign Country if your legal residence is in a foreign country.

Title: FAFSA Question 19
Summary: Question 19 is asking if you have been a legal resident of the state you live in for at least five years. Select Yes if you became a legal resident of the state you entered in question 18 before January 1, 2016. Select No if you became a legal resident of the state you entered in question 18 on or after January 1, 2016.

Title: FAFSA Question 20
Summary: Question 20 is asking how long you have been a legal resident of the state you live in. You indicated you were not a legal resident of the state entered in the state of legal residence question before January 1, 2016. You must type the month and year you became a legal resident.

Title: FAFSA Question 21
Summary: Question 21 is asking for your gender assigned at birth. Your gender is used to determine if you need to register with the Selective Service System. Most male citizens and male immigrants must register with the Selective Service System to receive federal student aid. This requirement applies to any person assigned the sex of male at birth. If you are transgender and need additional guidance, please visit https://transequality.org/issues/resources/selective-service-and-transgender-people

Title: FAFSA Question 22
Summary: Question 22 is asking if you would like to be automatically registered in the Selective Service System using the information on the FAFSA form. If you are assigned male at birth (age 18-25) and not registered with the Selective Service System, select Yes and the Selective Service System will register you. You can also register over the Internet at https://www.sss.gov.

Title: FAFSA Question 23
Summary: Question 23 is asking if you have any drug convictions that took place while you were receiving federal student aid. This question cannot be left blank. If you answer "Yes" to this question, you can still complete and submit the FAFSA. You will receive an additional worksheet to fill out to make sure you are still eligible for aid. If you have never applied for financial aid before, select "No."

Title: FAFSA Question 24
Summary: Question 24 is asking for one of your parents' highest level of education. Some states offer aid by the highest level of education your parents have completed. Select the answer that best describes your parent's highest level of education completed.

Title: FAFSA Question 25
Summary: Question 25 is asking for one of your parents' highest level of education. Some states offer aid by the highest level of education your parents have completed. Select the answer that best describes your parent's highest level of education completed. This should not be the same parent from question 24.

Title: FAFSA Question 26
Summary: Question 26 is asking for what level of education you will have completed before you begin college in the relevant school year. Select if you will have completed a high school diploma, a GED, homeschooling or none of the above.

Title: FAFSA Question 27
Summary: Question 27 is asking where you will complete your high school education, Enter the name, city, and state of the high school where you received or will receive your high school diploma.

Title: FAFSA Question 28
Summary: Question 28 is asking if you will have a bachelor's degree when you start the school year the FAFSA form is for. This question cannot be left blank. This question is primarily for graduate students or individuals returning to college later in life. If you are have never been to college, or previously went to college but did not graduate with a bachelor's degree, select "No."

Title: FAFSA Question 29
Summary: Question 29 is asking for your current grade level in college. This question cannot be left blank. Select your grade level in college. If you are currently a senior in high school or will be a first-time college student, select Never attended college/1st yr. “Grade level” does not mean the number of years you have attended college, but refers to your grade level in regard to completing your degree or certificate. A student who is not enrolled fulltime will require more years than a full-time student to reach the same grade level.

Title: FAFSA Question 30
Summary: Question 30 is asking what degree or certificate you will be pursuing in the school year this FAFSA form applies to. Select the degree or certificate that you will be working toward during the school year. If your degree or certificate does not fit into any of the categories listed below or if you are undecided, select Other/undecided from the list. Specific types of federal student aid are not applicable to certain programs.

Title: FAFSA Question 31
Summary: Question 31 is asking if you are interested in work study programs. The Federal Work-Study Program provides jobs for undergraduate and graduate students with financial need, allowing them to earn money to help pay educational expenses. All students will be considered for federal student grants and loans. You can decline any financial aid that is offered to you, including Federal Work-Study.

Title: FAFSA Step Two
Summary:
Step Two of the FAFSA asks for financial information relevant to your federal tax return. The year of the tax return you need will be on your FAFSA form. If you have never been married or are separated, divorced, or widowed, you only need to fill in information about yourself. If you are married, you will need to include information on yourself and your spouse.

You may be able to use the IRS Data Retrieval Tool if you are filling out the FAFSA electronically. This tool can automatically retrieve information from your tax return to help save you time. For more information, please visit https://studentaid.gov/resources/irs-drt-text

Title: FAFSA Question 32
Summary: Question 32 is asking if you have filed a tax return for a specific year. If you earned any money from a job with a company, you should have forms to complete a tax return, if you haven't done so already. If you didn't earn any money, you don't need to file a tax return. If you have not filed yet but will file one for the given year, you can use the previous year's tax return if you anticipate your income to be similar for both years.

Title: FAFSA Question 33
Summary: Question 33 is asking what kind of tax return you have filed or will file for the given year. If you are filing electronically, the answer to this question may be pre-filled with “Transferred from the IRS.”

Title: FAFSA Question 34
Summary: Question 34 is asking your tax filing status for the given year. Enter the tax filing status you used to file your taxes for that year. If you are filing electronically, the answer to this question may be pre-filled with “Transferred from the IRS.”

Title: FAFSA Question 35
Summary:
Question 35 is asking if you (and your spouse, if married) filed a Schedule 1 with your tax return. A Schedule 1 goes through specific additional income and adjustments to your income outside of a standard job, with entries for self-employment, interest for existing student loans, unemployment income, and other sources. If you did not file a Schedule 1, select "No."

The FAFSA will list specific items that, if you filed a Schedule 1 form for only those reasons, you can select "No" for this question, even if you did file a Schedule 1.

If you filed a Schedule 1 with your tax return for reasons not listed as exempt, select "Yes."

Title: FAFSA Question 36
Summary: Question 36 is asking for your (and your spouse's, if married) adjusted gross income from your tax return. Enter your adjusted gross income from your tax return in whole dollars. The FAFSA form should tell you which line of your tax return you can find this information on. If you are filing electronically, the answer to this question may be pre-filled with “Transferred from the IRS.”

Title: FAFSA Question 37
Summary: Question 37 is asking is for the amount you (and your spouse, if married) paid, according your tax return. Enter your income tax paid from your tax return in whole dollars. The FAFSA form should tell you which line of your tax return you can find this information on. If you are filing electronically, the answer to this question may be pre-filled with “Transferred from the IRS.”

Title: FAFSA Question 38
Summary: Question 38 is asking how much money you made from working during the year listed. Even if you didn't file a tax return, you will have to enter any money you made for this question. Enter the amount in whole dollars. If you filed a tax return for that year, the FAFSA form should tell you which line of your tax return you can find this information on. If you are filing electronically, the answer to this question may be pre-filled with “Transferred from the IRS.” If you had no income for the given year, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 39
Summary: Question 39 is asking how much money your spouse made from working during the year listed. Even if your spouse didn't file a tax return, you will have to enter any money they made for this question. Enter the amount in whole dollars. If your spouse filed a tax return for that year, the FAFSA form should tell you which line of their tax return you can find this information on. If you are filing electronically and you and your spouse filed your tax return jointly, the answer to this question may be pre-filled with “Transferred from the IRS.” If your spouse had no income for the given year, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 40
Summary: Question 40 is asking how much money you (and your spouse, if married) have in cash, savings, and checking accounts. If you have a checking and/or savings account with a bank or credit union, enter the total amounts of those accounts as of the date you are filling out and submitting the FAFSA form. If you and your spouse have separate bank accounts, you will still need to include the bank balance(s) of your spouse in this answer.

Title: FAFSA Question 41
Summary: Question 41 is asking for the total value of any investments you (and your spouse, if married) have made. If you or your spouse have no investments, or your investments have a negative value, enter 0. Investments are defined in the Notes section of the FAFSA (page 9 on the paper form).

Title: FAFSA Question 42
Summary: Question 42 is asking for the total value of any businesses or investment farms you (and your spouse, if married) have. If you or your spouse have no businesses or investment farms, or they have a negative value, enter 0. Investments are defined in the Notes section of the FAFSA (page 9 on the paper form).

Title: FAFSA Question 43
Summary: Question 43 is asking for specific financial information from the student. This information can usually be found on your tax forms. The specific question may reference where you can find this information the relevant tax form. If you are filing electronically, the answer to this question may be pre-filled with “Transferred from the IRS.” If a specific line item does not apply to you, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 43a
Summary: Question 43a is asking if you (or your spouse, if married) received any education credits on your taxes. If you are filing electronically, the answer to this question may be pre-filled with “Transferred from the IRS.” If you or your spouse did not receive any education credits, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 43b
Summary: Question 43b is asking if you  (or your spouse, if married) paid any child support due to a divorce or separation. This does not include any children living with you. If you did not pay any child support for any reason, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 43c
Summary: Question 43c is asking if you  (or your spouse, if married) made any money from need-based employment programs, such as work study. If you or your spouse did not make any money from these programs for any reason, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 43d
Summary: Question 43d is asking if you  (or your spouse, if married) received any taxable grant or scholarship money that you reported as income on your tax return. This includes fellowships and assistantships. If you or your spouse did not receive any money from grants, scholarships, assistantships, or fellowships that you had to report as income, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 43e
Summary:
Question 43e is asking if you  (or your spouse, if married) received combat pay or special combat pay. This applies to members of the United States Armed Forces who fought in high-risk combat zones. For more information on combat pay, please visit https://www.1040.com/tax-guide/faq/what-is-combat-pay/

 If you or your spouse did not receive any combat pay or special combat pay, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 43f
Summary: Question 43f is asking if you  (or your spouse, if married) received any money from working in a cooperative education program offered by your college. If you or your spouse did not receive any money from these programs or have not previously attended college, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 44
Summary: Question 44 is asking for any untaxed income you (or your spouse, if married) made during the specific year given on the FAFSA form. Most students still in high school will not have any additional income that would qualify to be reported here.

Title: FAFSA Question 44a
Summary: Question 44a is asking if you (or your spouse, if married) made payments to tax-deferred pension plans or retirement savings plans. If you or your spouse did not make payments to these plans for any reason, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 44b
Summary: Question 44b is asking if you (or your spouse, if married) made any deductions or payments to specific qualified plans as outlined on Schedule 1 of your tax return. If you or your spouse did not make any deductions or payments to these plans, or did not file a Schedule 1, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 44c
Summary: Question 44c is asking if you (or your spouse, if married) received any child support payments for any of your children. This does not apply to foster care or adoption payments. If you or your spouse did not receive these payments or you have no children, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 44d
Summary: Question 44d is asking if you (or your spouse, if married) received any income from interest that you didn't need to pay taxes on. If you are filing electronically, the answer to this question may be pre-filled with “Transferred from the IRS.” If you or your spouse did not receive any income from this source, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 44e
Summary: Question 44e is asking if you (or your spouse, if married) received any pensions or distributions from an IRA.  If you are filing electronically, the answer to this question may be pre-filled with “Transferred from the IRS.” If you or your spouse did not receive any income from this source, or the amount is negative, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 44f
Summary: Question 44fis asking if you (or your spouse, if married) received any sort of living allowance paid to members of the military or clergy. On-base military housing or basic military allowances for housing don't count for this. Cash payments and cash value of benefits do count for this. If you or your spouse did not receive any income from this source, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 44g
Summary: Question 44g is asking if you (or your spouse, if married) received any non-education benefits from being a veteran of the US military. If you or your spouse did not receive any income from this source or are not veterans of the military, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 44h
Summary: Question 44h is asking if you (or your spouse, if married) received any other money you didn't pay taxes on, such as disability benefits and workers' compensation. If you or your spouse did not receive any income from these sources, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 44i
Summary: Question 44i is asking if you (or your spouse, if married) had any other money received or paid on your behalf, such as bills, that you have not already included on this form. This money includes prepaid tuition plans, such as a 529 plan.

Title: FAFSA Step Three
Summary: Section Three determines if you wil need your parents to complete Step Four. If you respond "Yes" to any question, you can skip Step Four entirely and move on to Step Five.

Title: FAFSA Question 45
Summary:
Question 45 is asking to confirm you are 23 years of age or older. Answer yes if your birthday is before January 1st, 1998. 

If the answer to this question is Yes, skip down to Step Five on the FAFSA Form.

Title: FAFSA Question 46
Summary:
Question 46 is asking to confirm if you are married. Answer yes if you are married as of today. Also answer yes if you are separated but not divorced.

If the answer to this question is Yes, skip down to Step Five on the FAFSA Form.

Title: FAFSA Question 47
Summary: Question 47 is asking if you are working on an advanced degree, such as a master's degree or doctorate. If you will be working on an advanced degree for the school year you're filling out the FAFSA for, skip down to Step Five on the FAFSA Form.

Title: FAFSA Question 48
Summary:
Question 48 is asking to confirm if you are in the military on active duty. Select Yes if you are currently serving in the U.S. Armed Forces or are a National Guard or Reserves enlistee who is on active duty for other than state or training purposes.

If you are a National Guard or Reserves enlistee who is on active duty for state or training purposes, or if you are not currently serving on active duty in the U.S. Armed Forces, do not check the box.

If the answer to this question is Yes, skip down to Step Five on the FAFSA Form.

Title: FAFSA Question 49
Summary:
Question 49 is asking if you are a veteran of the U.S. Armed Forces. Select Yes if you have engaged in active duty (including basic training) in the U.S. Armed Forces (Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines, or Coast Guard), or are a National Guard or Reserve enlistee who was called to active duty for other than state or training purposes, or were a cadet or midshipman at one of the service academies, and were released under a condition other than dishonorable. Also check the box if you are not a veteran now but will be one by June 30, 2022.

Do not check the box if you:
Are currently serving in the U.S. Armed Forces and will continue to serve through June 30, 2022
Have never engaged in active duty (including basic training) in the U.S. Armed Forces
Are currently an ROTC student, a cadet or midshipman at a service academy
Are a National Guard or Reserves enlistee activated only for state or training purposes,  
Were engaged in active duty in the U.S. Armed Forces but released under dishonorable conditions.

 If the answer to this question is Yes, skip down to Step Five on the FAFSA Form.

Title: FAFSA Question 50
Summary:
Question 50 is asking if you have children you provide primary support for. Select Yes if you have children (or are expecting a child who will be born before or during the school year) and your child(ren) receive(s) more than half of their support from you (and if married, your spouse).

Select No if you do not have children. Also select No if your children are not receiving more than half of their support from you (and if married, your spouse).

If the answer to this question is Yes, skip down to Step Five on the FAFSA Form.

Title: FAFSA Question 51
Summary:
Question 51 is asking if you have dependents who are not your children that you provide primary support for. Select Yes if other people (not your children or spouse) live with you. These other dependents must also be receiving more than half of their support from you and will continue to receive more than half of their support from you through June 30, 2022. 
 
Select No if you do not have dependents (other than your children or spouse). Also select No if you have dependents, but they are not receiving more than half of their support from you.

If the answer to this question is Yes, skip down to Step Five on the FAFSA Form.

Title: FAFSA Question 52
Summary:
Question 52 is asking if your parents are deceased or if you have been a ward or dependent of the court as a teenager. Select Yes if:
You had no living parent (biological or adoptive) at any time since you turned age 13, even if you are now adopted.
You were in foster care at any time since you turned age 13, even if you are no longer in foster care as of today.  
you were a dependent or ward of the court at any time since you turned age 13, even if you are no longer a dependent/ward of the court as of today. For federal student aid purposes, someone who is incarcerated is not considered a ward of the court. 
  
If you are not sure if you were in foster care, check with your state child welfare agency. You can find out the contact information for your state child welfare agency by visiting your state child welfare agency. The financial aid administrator at your college may require you to provide proof that you were in foster care or a dependent/ward of the court.

If the answer to this question is Yes, skip to Step Five on the FAFSA form.

Title: FAFSA Question 53
Summary: Question 53 is asking if you are an emancipated minor. If you answer Yes to this question, you may be required to provide proof that you are an emancipated minor from a court decision that comes from the state you legally resided in when the decision was made. If you are still a minor and the court decision is not in effect currently or was not in effect when you became an adult, select No. If you are not an emancipated minor, select No.

Title: FAFSA Question 54
Summary: Question 54 is asking if your legal guardian was not a parent or stepparent. If you answer Yes to this question, you may be required to provide proof of the court decision that identifies your legal guardian as someone other than a parent or stepparent. That court decision must come from the state you legally resided in when the decision was made. If the court decision for legal guardianship is not in effect currently or was not in effect when you became an adult, select No.

Title: FAFSA Question 55
Summary: Question 55 is asking if your school or school district considered you an unaccompanied youth that was homeless, or self-supporting and at risk of becoming homeless after July 1st of the year prior to the start of the school year for your FAFSA form. Answer “No” if you are not homeless or at risk of being homeless, or do not have a determination from your school or school district.

Title: FAFSA Question 56
Summary: Question 56 is asking if an emergency shelter or transitional housing program considered you an unaccompanied youth that was homeless, or self-supporting and at risk of becoming homeless after July 1st of the year prior to the start of the school year for your FAFSA form. Answer “No” if you are not homeless or at risk of being homeless, or do not have a determination from an emergency shelter or transitional housing program.

Title: FAFSA Question 57
Summary: Question 56 is asking if a runaway/homeless youth center or transitional housing program considered you an unaccompanied youth that was homeless, or self-supporting and at risk of becoming homeless after July 1st of the year prior to the start of the school year for your FAFSA form. Answer “No” if you are not homeless or at risk of being homeless, or do not have a determination from a runaway/homeless youth center  or transitional housing program.

Title: Step Four Overview
Summary: Step Four of the FAFSA form asks for personal information about the student's parents, including name, address, identification numbers, education level, and financial details. If you answered "Yes" to any of the questions in Step Three, you can skip Step Four entirely. If your legal parents are married to each other, or are not married to each other and live together, answer the questions about both of them. If your parent was never married or is remarried, divorced, separated or widowed, see StudentAid.gov/fafsa-parent for additional instructions.

Title: FAFSA Question 58
Summary: Question 58 is asking if your parents were ever married. Select the option that best describes your parents' relationship.

Title: FAFSA Question 59
Summary: Question 59 is asking for the date that your parent's marital status changed (marriage, divorce, separation, or spouse's death). If your parents have never been married, you can leave this blank.

Title: FAFSA Question 60
Summary: Question 60 is asking for one of your parents' Social Security Number. Enter their Social Security Number as it appears on their Social Security card. If your parent does not have a Social Security Number, you must enter 000-00-0000. If they have a Social Security Number, but don't remember it or don't have access to their Social Security card due to misplacement or other factors, they can request a new or replacement card from the Social Security Administration here: https://www.ssa.gov/ssnumber/

Title: FAFSA Question 61
Summary: Question 61 is asking for your parent's last name. Enter in their last name as it appears on their Social Security card, if applicable.

Title: FAFSA Question 62
Summary: Question 62 is asking for your parent's first initial. Enter in the first letter of their first name as it appears on their Social Security card, if applicable.

Title: FAFSA Question 63
Summary: Question 63 is asking for your parent's date of birth. Enter their date of birth in “mmddyyyy” format. For example, if their birthday is May 3, 1975, enter 05031975.

Title: FAFSA Question 64
Summary: Question 64 is asking for one of your parents' Social Security Number. This must be a different parent from the one you identified in question 60. Enter their Social Security Number as it appears on their Social Security card. If your parent does not have a Social Security Number, you must enter 000-00-0000. If they have a Social Security Number, but don't remember it or don't have access to their Social Security card due to misplacement or other factors, they can request a new or replacement card from the Social Security Administration here: https://www.ssa.gov/ssnumber/

Title: FAFSA Question 65
Summary: Question 65 is asking for your parent's last name. Enter in their last name as it appears on their Social Security card, if applicable.

Title: FAFSA Question 66
Summary: Question 66 is asking for your parent's first initial. Enter in the first letter of their first name as it appears on their Social Security card, if applicable.

Title: FAFSA Question 67
Summary: Question 67 is asking for your parent's date of birth. Enter their date of birth in “mmddyyyy” format. For example, if their birthday is May 3, 1975, enter 05031975.

Title: FAFSA Question 68
Summary: Question 68 is asking for your parents' email address. Enter their e-mail address so they can receive a notification when your FAFSA form has been processed. A valid email address usually looks like this matt@yahoo.com or ashley@gmail.com.

Title: FAFSA Question 69
Summary: Question 69 is asking for which state your parents live in. Enter or select their current state or country of legal residence. If you live with your parents, this will be the same answer as question 18.

Title: FAFSA Question 70
Summary: Question 70 is asking if your parents have been a legal resident of the state they live in for at least five years. Select Yes if they became a legal resident of the state you entered in question 69 before January 1, 2016. Select No if they became a legal resident of the state you entered in question 69 on or after January 1, 2016. If you live with your parents, this may be the same answer as question 19.

Title: FAFSA Question 71
Summary: Question 71 is asking how long your parents have been a legal resident of the state they live in. You indicated they were not a legal resident of the state entered in the state of legal residence question before January 1, 2016. You must type the month and year they became legal residents. If you live with your parents, this may be the same answer as question 20.

Title: FAFSA Question 72
Summary: Question 72 is asking how many people are in your parents' household. This includes yourself (even if you do not live with your parents), your parents, and other children or individuals for whom your parents provide more than half their support and will continue to do so through the school year indicated on your FAFSA form.

Title: FAFSA Question 73
Summary: Question 73 is asking how many people in your parents' household, aside from themselves or siblings in a military academy, will be college students for the given year on your FAFSA form. You, as a student, always count for this question!

Title: FAFSA Question 74
Summary: Question 74 is asking if you, your parents, or anyone in your household (counted in question 72) received benefits from Medicaid or Supplemental Security Income. If someone in your household did receive these benefits, check the box.

Title: FAFSA Question 75
Summary: Question 75 is asking if you, your parents, or anyone in your household (counted in question 72) received benefits from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP). If someone in your household did receive these benefits, check the box.

Title: FAFSA Question 76
Summary: Question 75 is asking if you, your parents, or anyone in your household (counted in question 72) qualified for free or Reduced Price School Lunch. If someone in your household did qualify, check the box.

Title: FAFSA Question 77
Summary:
Question 77 is asking if you, your parents, or anyone in your household (counted in question 72) received benefits from Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF). Your state may have a different name for this program. To verify the program name for your state, please visit https://aspe.hhs.gov/dataset/tanf-program-names

If someone in your household did receive these benefits, check the box.

Title: FAFSA Question 78
Summary: Question 78 is asking if you, your parents, or anyone in your household (counted in question 72) received benefits from the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children (WIC). If someone in your household did receive these benefits, check the box.

Title: FAFSA Question 79
Summary: Question 79 is asking if your parents have filed a tax return for a specific year. If they have not filed yet but will file one for the given year, they can use the previous year's tax return if they anticipate their income to be similar for both years.

Title: FAFSA Question 80
Summary: Question 80 is asking what kind of tax return your parents have filed or will file for the given year. This will likely be a 1040 or 1040 EZ.

Title: FAFSA Question 81
Summary: Question 81 is asking your parents' tax filing status for the given year. Enter the tax filing status they used to file their taxes for that year.

Title: FAFSA Question 82
Summary:
Question 82 is asking if your parents filed a Schedule 1 with your tax return. A Schedule 1 goes through specific additional income and adjustments to your income outside of a standard job, with entries for self-employment, interest for existing student loans, unemployment income, and other sources. If they did not file a Schedule 1, select "No."

The FAFSA will list specific items that, if your parentls filed a Schedule 1 form for only those reasons, you can select "No" for this question, even if they did file a Schedule 1.

If they filed a Schedule 1 with their tax return for reasons not listed as exempt, select "Yes."

Title: FAFSA Question 83
Summary: Question 83 is asking if your parents or stepparents are dislocated workers, either due to layoffs, economic conditions, natural disasters, or previously occupied as a homemaker and struggling to find employment. You may be required to provide proof that your parents or stepparents are dislocated workers.

Title: FAFSA Question 84
Summary: Question 84 is asking for your parents' adjusted gross income from their tax returns. Enter their total adjusted gross income from their tax returns in whole dollars. The FAFSA form should tell you which line of their tax return you can find this information on.

Title: FAFSA Question 85
Summary: Question 85 is asking is for the amount your parents paid, according their tax returns. Enter their total income tax paid from their tax returns in whole dollars. The FAFSA form should tell you which line of your tax return you can find this information on.

Title: FAFSA Question 86
Summary: Question 86 is asking how much money one of your parents made from working during the year listed. Even if they didn't file a tax return, you will have to enter any money they made for this question. Enter the amount in whole dollars. If they filed a tax return for that year, the FAFSA form should tell you which line of their tax return you can find this information on.

Title: FAFSA Question 87
Summary: Question 87 is asking how much money one of your parents made from working during the year listed (not the same parent from question 86). Even if they didn't file a tax return, you will have to enter any money they made for this question. Enter the amount in whole dollars. If they filed a tax return for that year, the FAFSA form should tell you which line of their tax return you can find this information on.

Title: FAFSA Question 88
Summary: Question 88 is asking how much money your parents have in cash, savings, and checking accounts. Your parents may not provide you with exact numbers, but they should provide a number that is close to the correct total.

Title: FAFSA Question 89
Summary: Question 89 is asking for the total value of any investments your parents have made. If your parents have no investments, or your investments have a negative value, enter 0. Investments are defined in the Notes section of the FAFSA (page 9 on the paper form).

Title: FAFSA Question 90
Summary: 90 is asking for the total value of any businesses or investment farms your parents have. If your parents have no businesses or investment farms, or they have a negative value, enter 0. Investments are defined in the Notes section of the FAFSA (page 9 on the paper form).

Title: FAFSA Question 91
Summary: Question 91 is asking for specific financial information from your parents or stepparents. This information can usually be found on their tax forms. The specific question may reference where you can find this information the relevant tax form. If a specific line item does not apply to them, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 91a
Summary: Question 91a is asking if your parents or stepparents) received any education credits on your taxes. If your parents or stepparents did not receive any education credits, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 91b
Summary: Question 91b is asking if your parents or stepparents  paid any child support due to a divorce or separation. This does not include any children living with them. If your parents or stepparents did not pay any child support for any reason, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 91c
Summary: Question 91c is asking if your parents or stepparents made any money from need-based employment programs, such as work study. If your parents or stepparents  did not make any money from these programs for any reason, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 91d
Summary: Question 91d is asking if your parents or stepparents received any taxable grant or scholarship money that they reported as income on their tax returns. This includes fellowships and assistantships. If your parents or stepparents did not receive any money from grants, scholarships, assistantships, or fellowships that they had to report as income, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 91e
Summary:
Question 91e is asking if your parents or stepparents received combat pay or special combat pay. This applies to members of the United States Armed Forces who fought in high-risk combat zones. For more information on combat pay, please visit https://www.1040.com/tax-guide/faq/what-is-combat-pay/

 If your parents or stepparents  did not receive any combat pay or special combat pay, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 91f
Summary: Question 91f is asking if you  (or your spouse, if married) received any money from working in a cooperative education program offered by a college. If your parents or stepparents  did not receive any money from these programs, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 92
Summary: Question 92 is asking for any untaxed income your parents or stepparents made during the specific year given on the FAFSA form. Some of this is on your parents' tax returns.

Title: FAFSA Question 92a
Summary: Question 92a is asking if your parents or stepparentsmade payments to tax-deferred pension plans or retirement savings plans. If they did not make payments to these plans for any reason, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 92b
Summary: Question 92b is asking if your parents or stepparents made any deductions or payments to specific qualified plans as outlined on Schedule 1 of your tax return. If they did not make any deductions or payments to these plans, or did not file a Schedule 1, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 92c
Summary: Question 92c is asking if your parents or stepparents received any child support payments for any of their children, including you. This does not apply to foster care or adoption payments. If your parents or stepparents did not receive these payments, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 92d
Summary: Question 92d is asking if your parents or stepparents received any income from interest they didn't need to pay taxes on. If your parents or stepparents did not receive any income from this source, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 92e
Summary: Question 92e is asking if your parents or stepparents received any pensions or distributions from an IRA.  If they did not receive any income from this source, or the amount is negative, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 92f
Summary: Question 92f is asking if your parents or stepparents received any sort of living allowance paid to members of the military or clergy. On-base military housing or basic military allowances for housing don't count for this. Cash payments and cash value of benefits do count for this. If your parents or stepparents did not receive any income from this source, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 92g
Summary: Question 92g is asking if your parents or stepparents received any non-education benefits from being a veteran of the US military. If they did not receive any income from this source or are not veterans of the military, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Question 92h
Summary: Question 92h is asking if your parents or stepparents received any other money you didn't pay taxes on, such as disability benefits and workers' compensation. If they did not receive any income from these sources, enter 0.

Title: FAFSA Step Five
Summary: Step Five is only required if you answered Yes to any questions in Step Three. If you answered No to all questions in Step Three, you can skip this section.

Title: FAFSA Question 93
Summary: Question 93 is asking how many people are in your parents' household. This includes yourself, and where applicable, your spouse, your children, and other individuals for whom you provide more than half their support and will continue to do so through the school year indicated on your FAFSA form.

Title: FAFSA Question 94
Summary: Question 94 is asking how many people in your household, aside from family members in a military academy, will be college students for the given year on your FAFSA form. You, as a student, always count for this question!

Title: FAFSA Question 95
Summary: Question 95 is asking if you, your spouse, or anyone in your household (counted in question 93) received benefits from Medicaid or Supplemental Security Income. If someone in your household did receive these benefits, check the box.

Title: FAFSA Question 96
Summary: Question 96 is asking if you, your spouse, or anyone in your household (counted in question 93) received benefits from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP). If someone in your household did receive these benefits, check the box.

Title: FAFSA Question 97
Summary: Question 97 is asking if you, your spouse, or anyone in your household (counted in question 93) qualified for free or Reduced Price School Lunch. If someone in your household did qualify, check the box.

Title: FAFSA Question 98
Summary:
Question 98 is asking if you, your parents, or anyone in your household (counted in question 93) received benefits from Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF). Your state may have a different name for this program. To verify the program name for your state, please visit https://aspe.hhs.gov/dataset/tanf-program-names

If someone in your household did receive these benefits, check the box.

Title: FAFSA Question 99
Summary: Question 99 is asking if you, your parents, or anyone in your household (counted in question 93) received benefits from the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children (WIC). If someone in your household did receive these benefits, check the box.

Title: FAFSA Question 100
Summary: Question 100 is asking if you or your spouse is a dislocated worker, either due to layoffs, economic conditions, natural disasters, or previously occupied as a homemaker and struggling to find employment. You may be required to provide proof that you are a dislocated worker.

Title: Step Six Overview
Summary: Step Six is asking where you want to send your FAFSA information. These should be the colleges you are planning to apply to. The paper form allows for up to four colleges to be listed. Instructions on how to send your information to more colleges is available on page 2 of the paper form, or at www.fafsa.gov.

Title: FAFSA Question 101
Summary: Question 101 is asking where you want to send your FAFSA information. These should be the colleges you are planning to apply to.

Title: FAFSA Question 101a
Summary:
Question 101a is asking for the federal school code of the first college you want to receive your FAFSA information. This should be one of the colleges you are applying to. You can look up federal school codes here: https://fafsa.ed.gov/spa/fsc/#/SEARCH?locale=en_US

If you don't know or can't find the federal school code for your college, you can include the name, address, city, and state of the college instead.

Title: FAFSA Question 101b
Summary: Question 101b is asking where you plan to live at the first college you want to receive your FAFSA information. This information applies to the given school year your FAFSA applies to. If you plan to live in the college's dorms or other, on-campus housing, select "on-campus." If you plan to live with your parents while attending this school, select "with parents." If you plan to live somewhere not on campus, but not with your parents, select "off-campus."

Title: FAFSA Question 101c
Summary:
Question 101c is asking for the federal school code of the second college you want to receive your FAFSA information. This should be one of the colleges you are applying to. You can look up federal school codes here: https://fafsa.ed.gov/spa/fsc/#/SEARCH?locale=en_US

If you don't know or can't find the federal school code for your college, you can include the name, address, city, and state of the college instead.

Title: FAFSA Question 101d
Summary: Question 101bdis asking where you plan to live at the second college you want to receive your FAFSA information. This information applies to the given school year your FAFSA applies to. If you plan to live in the college's dorms or other, on-campus housing, select "on-campus." If you plan to live with your parents while attending this school, select "with parents." If you plan to live somewhere not on campus, but not with your parents, select "off-campus."

Title: FAFSA Question 101e
Summary:
Question 101e is asking for the federal school code of the third college you want to receive your FAFSA information. This should be one of the colleges you are applying to. You can look up federal school codes here: https://fafsa.ed.gov/spa/fsc/#/SEARCH?locale=en_US

If you don't know or can't find the federal school code for your college, you can include the name, address, city, and state of the college instead.

Title: FAFSA Question 101f
Summary: Question 101f is asking where you plan to live at the third college you want to receive your FAFSA information. This information applies to the given school year your FAFSA applies to. If you plan to live in the college's dorms or other, on-campus housing, select "on-campus." If you plan to live with your parents while attending this school, select "with parents." If you plan to live somewhere not on campus, but not with your parents, select "off-campus."

Title: FAFSA Question 101g
Summary:
Question 101g is asking for the federal school code of the fourth college you want to receive your FAFSA information. This should be one of the colleges you are applying to. You can look up federal school codes here: https://fafsa.ed.gov/spa/fsc/#/SEARCH?locale=en_US

If you don't know or can't find the federal school code for your college, you can include the name, address, city, and state of the college instead.

Title: FAFSA Question 101h
Summary: Question 101h is asking where you plan to live at the fourth college you want to receive your FAFSA information. This information applies to the given school year your FAFSA applies to. If you plan to live in the college's dorms or other, on-campus housing, select "on-campus." If you plan to live with your parents while attending this school, select "with parents." If you plan to live somewhere not on campus, but not with your parents, select "off-campus."

Title: Step Seven Overview
Summary: This is the last step! You've done great so far. Now, all you have to do is provide the date you completed the form, sign it, and have your parents sign it. If you paid someone to help you fill out this form, you'll have to include their information as well.

Title: FAFSA Question 102
Summary: Question 102 is the date you completed the FAFSA form. Enter the month and day, then select the appropriate year for when you completed the form.

Title: FAFSA Question 103
Summary: Question 103 is your signature and, if you completed Step Four, a signature from one of your parents. If filing electronically, you will sign your form with your FSA ID.

Title: FAFSA Question 104
Summary: If someone was paid to help you prepare this form, they must fill out this information. You don't need to do it!

Title: FAFSA Question 105
Summary: If someone was paid to help you prepare this form, they must fill out this section. You don't need to do it!

Title: FAFSA Question 106
Summary: If someone was paid to help you prepare this form, they must fill out this information. You don't need to do it!

Title: [INSTITUTION] FAFSA Deadline
Summary:
Please turn in your FAFSA form to [LOCATION] by [DATE].

Note to Admin: Please update this response based on your institution's specific deadline.

Title: Education Level
Summary: If you are an American citizen, you are eligible for aid if you have received a high school diploma, received a General Educational Development (GED) certificate, or completed a high school education in a homeschool setting approved under law for your state.

Title: Homeschool Eligibility
Summary: Different states have different education requirements for homeschooling. In Nebraska and Vermont, education requirements come from local school boards. For information relevant to your state, please visit https://www.homeschool.com/articles/high-school-graduation-requirements-by-state/

Title: Selective Service or Draft
Summary: Male students must be registered with Selective Service to receive federal student aid. Male students who are 18-25 years old can register for Selective Service. For more information, please visit https://www.sss.gov/

Title: Social Security Number
Summary:
To receive federal student aid, you must have a valid Social Security number. For more information on obtaining or reclaiming your Social Security number and/or card, please visit https://www.ssa.gov/ssnumber/

If you are from the Republic of the Marshall Islands, Federated States of Micronesia, or the Republic of Palau, you do not need a valid Social Security number.

Title: Approved use of money
Summary: When you complete the FAFSA, you sign a statement to certify you will use any money you get from federal student aid for educational purposes only and that you do not already owe money, due to a grant refund or another federal student loan going into default. This statement is in Step Seven
